metadata.case_name: The Collector of Bombay v. Trustees under Exhibit B (Lady Pochkhanawalla and others)

facts.text: Lands situated within the City of Bombay originally known as Foras lands, rights of occupants settled by Bombay Act No. VI of 1851.
Between 1864 and 1867, Government acquired these lands for B.B. & C.I. Railway under Land Acquisition Act No. VI of 1857.
On 22-11-1938, lands no longer required for Railway, sold by Governor-General to Lady Pochkhanawalla and others as joint tenants under deed Exhibit A.
On 28-3-1939, survivor of purchasers conveyed lands in trust under Exhibit B; respondents are trustees appointed under that deed.
In April 1942, appellant (Collector) acting under Bombay Act No. II of 1876 issued notices to respondents proposing to levy assessment at specified rates.
Respondents replied denying right to assess; instituted suits Nos. 7 and 23 of 1943 before Revenue Judge for declaration of rights.

In plaints, respondents alleged under Foras Act maximum assessment 9 reas per burga, no right to enhance; land acquisition extinguished even this; purchased absolutely under Exhibit A, entitled to hold revenue-free.

Revenue Judge held land acquisition vested lands in Government free from liability to pay assessment; transfer under Exhibit A without reservation gave purchasers right to hold without revenue liability; declared no right to levy, notices illegal. Decree dated 17-03-1945.

High Court of Bombay (Chagla CJ, Bhagwati J concurring) in Appeal from Original Decree No. 274 of 1945: Foras Act imposed specific limit; land acquisition extinguished even that right; transferred as revenue-free. Appeal dismissed. Judgment dated 10-11-1948.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.
Historical background: Island of Bombay ceded by Portugal to British Crown 1661 as dowry; granted to East India Company 1668; reclamation in 18th century, Foras payments introduced.
Assessment on Foras lands at 9 reas per burga from 1858 until acquisition, as per Exhibit N.
Respondents at all stages claimed immunity based on s.8 of Act II 1876 as superior holders; did not dispute superior holder status until SC arguments.

legal_issues.text: Whether the lands are liable to be assessed to revenue under s.8 Bombay City Land Revenue Act No. II of 1876, or if respondents have right in limitation thereof.
Effect of Foras Act No. VI of 1851 on right to assess/enhance assessment.
Effect of land acquisition proceedings 1864-67 under Land Acquisition Act No. VI of 1857 on Government's right to levy assessment.
Whether sale deed Exhibit A dated 22-11-1938 imposes limitation on right to assess.

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondents are superior holders; no specific right limiting assessment under s.8 Act II 1876 proved; Foras Act conferred permanent tenure but not permanent assessment; right to enhance preserved.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay City Land Revenue Act No. II of 1876 s.8; Shapurji Jivanji v. Collector of Bombay (1885 ILR 9 Bom 483)

petitioner_arguments.text: Land acquisition under Act VI 1857 only extinguished private interests, not Government's prerogative right to assess.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Land Acquisition Act No. VI of 1857 s.VIII; Govt of Bombay v. Esupali Salebhai (1909 ILR 34 Bom 618); Deputy Collector Calicut v. Aiyavu Pillay (1911 9 IC 341)

petitioner_arguments.text: Exhibit A absolute sale but expressly subject to all cesses, taxes, rates, assessments; no reservation needed for sovereign right; cannot imply revenue-free.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Crown Grants Act No. XV of 1895 s.3 (limited scope)

petitioner_arguments.text: Foras tenure extinguished by acquisition; lands sold as freehold, not Foras lands; Foras Act repealed 1870.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Land Acquisition Act No. VI of 1857 s.VIII; Bombay Act No. XIV of 1870

petitioner_arguments.text: New contention in SC that respondents not superior holders barred as inconsistent with prior stand, requires new facts.

respondent_arguments.text: Under Foras Act, maximum assessment 9 reas per burga, no right to enhance.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay Foras Act No. VI of 1851 s.2

respondent_arguments.text: Land acquisition extinguished Government's right to assess as an 'interest' in land; compensation paid implicitly.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Land Acquisition Act No. VI of 1857 s.VIII; Exhibit P

respondent_arguments.text: Absolute sale by Governor-General under Exhibit A conveys revenue-free; no reservation.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Crown Grants Act No. XV of 1895 s.3; Dadoba v. Collector of Bombay (1901 ILR 25 Bom 714)

respondent_arguments.text: In SC, lands held by outright sale, not as superior holders under derivative tenure from Provincial Govt.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay City Land Revenue Act No. II of 1876 s.3(4), s.8

respondent_arguments.text: Foras tenure incident annexed to lands, survives acquisition and sale; saved by repeal.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay Foras Act No. VI of 1851; Bombay Act No. XIV of 1870 s.1

court_reasoning.text: Proceed on basis respondents are superior holders under s.3(4) Act II 1876; burden on them to prove limitation under s.8 per Privy Council.
court_reasoning.key_observation: New contention on superior holder status barred.

court_reasoning.text: Foras Act s.2 extinguishes Company reversion, saves rents 'now severally payable' which continue payable; limits to then-current 9 reas per burga.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words 'now severally payable and which shall continue' impose specific limit despite inartistic drafting.

court_reasoning.text: Land acquisition vests land in Govt free from all OTHER estates/rights/interests; Govt's prerogative right to assess not acquired, outside private interests.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No valuation/compensation for Govt right in award; prerogative paramount to ownership.

court_reasoning.text: Exhibit A absolute conveyance subject to all cesses/taxes/assessments; no recital revenue-free; s.3 Crown Grants Act saves express limitations, none here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Clause expressly subjects to assessments; Dadoba distinguished as estoppel case.

court_reasoning.text: Foras tenure extinguished by acquisition; lands sold freehold; repeal of Foras Act 1870, no subsisting rights saved.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tenure incapable of revival; no inseverable incident survives absolute vesting in Govt.

holdings.text: Respondents have no right in limitation of appellant's right to assess under s.8 Act II 1876.
Foras Act limited assessment to 9 reas per burga at that time.
Land acquisition did not extinguish Govt's right to assess.
Exhibit A does not grant revenue-free holding.

precedents_cited.case_name: Goswamini Shri Kamala Vahooji v. Collector of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: s.8 allows plea of no right to assess; burden on superior holder to prove limitation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shapurji Jivanji v. The Collector of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Govt right to enhance Foras assessments under s.8.

precedents_cited.case_name: Government of Bombay v. Esupali Salebhai
precedents_cited.relevance: Govt need not acquire/pay for own interest in land acquisition.

precedents_cited.case_name: Deputy Collector, Calicut Division v. Aiyavu Pillay
precedents_cited.relevance: Land Acquisition Act does not contemplate acquiring Govt's own interest.
Estoppel/collateral contract from correspondence; not absolute sale implying revenue-free.

precedents_cited.case_name: Thakur Jagannath Baksh Singh v. The United Provinces
precedents_cited.relevance: s.3 Crown Grants Act read in context of preamble, limited to T.P. Act doubts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Collector of Bombay v. Municipal Corporation of the City of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Immunity as incident of prescriptive title; not surviving Govt acquisition.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay City Land Revenue Act No. II of 1876
statutes_cited.relevance: Authority to levy assessment on superior holders; limitation if specific right proved.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Foras Act No. VI of 1851
statutes_cited.relevance: Extinguished Company rights, saved then-current assessment as limit.

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition Act No. VI of 1857
statutes_cited.relevance: Vesting free from other interests; Govt assessment right not extinguished.

statutes_cited.name: Crown Grants Act No. XV of 1895
statutes_cited.relevance: Provisions/restrictions in Crown grants take effect per tenor; limited to T.P. Act issues.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Act No. XIV of 1870
statutes_cited.relevance: Repeal of Foras Act; saves accrued rights, none subsisting post-acquisition.

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition Act No. I of 1894
statutes_cited.relevance: Analogous; confirms only private interests acquired.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allows the appeal by special leave, reversing High Court and Revenue Judge; holds respondents have no right limiting Government's assessment under s.8 Act II 1876; lands liable to assessment at Collector's discretion.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration that appellant has right to levy assessment without limitation.

key_quotes.text: "When there is a right on the part of the superior holder in limitation of the right of Government... the assessment shall not exceed such specific limit."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.8 Act II 1876 central to controversy.

key_quotes.text: "the lands vest in the Government free from all other estates, rights, titles and interests."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key to holding land acquisition did not affect Govt assessment right.

key_quotes.text: "the true import of the clause... is that while... the right of the Government to recover the assessment is saved, it is... limited to the amount then payable."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets Foras Act s.2 as limiting to 9 reas per burga.

key_quotes.text: "the right to impose a tax on land is a prerogative right of the Crown, paramount to the ownership over the land and outside it."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Crux distinguishing Govt right from private interests.
